body:
These days, most people are using Babel, so browser support is irrelevant.

It'd still be useful to make the docs clearer, tho!

@ljharb That's a very generic statement and one, that I believe is totally false. There's a huge number of legacy sites that are still supported that do not use Babel, so browser support is very much relevant. It's better to say that in your experience it's irrelevant.

@ilyavolodin i should have qualified; irrelevant *for those users*. I‚Äôm curious where your data comes from about the large number of legacy sites that use updated eslint but don‚Äôt use Babel, but we can discuss that in a different medium :-)

> i should have qualified; irrelevant for those users

That's also a very broad statement. Most of the sites have a matrix of supported browsers. If they do not transpile their code, they have to write code that will run natively in those browsers, which includes understanding of which features are supported and which are not.
If you work for a modern company and are heavily involved in Open Source, it's really easy to think that everyone is writing modern WebApps and using Babel, Webpack, React and other popular tools. But in reality, that covers a rather small percentage of JS developers. I know, because I work with those developers every day.

Putting aside the discussion about what browsers people can support and whether or not some products use transpiling for the moment...

I think we can agree that we would welcome any clarity around which version of the ECMAScript specification introduces a feature such as object spread in our documentation. @vapier Would you like to submit a pull request?
üëç At a minimum, this should be mentioned in "When Not to Use It".

i started off by throwing up #11137 to get a sense of the process.  i can try cribbing the style from other pages once that goes through.

i agree that babel or any other tooling is irrelevant to the discussion.  many other eslint pages discuss standards availability.  fwiw, i use eslint, but have zero interest in anything like babel.

issue.title: [Snyk] Upgrade eslint from 5.7.0 to 5.16.0

repository.name: hpropagate
repository.description: Node.js module for propagating http headers from incoming requests to the corresponding outgoing requests automatically

issue.body:
Snyk have raised this PR to upgrade `eslint` from 5.7.0 to 5.16.0. - The recommended version is **15 minor versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **5 months ago**, on 2019-03-30.
Release notes

    • dfef227 Build: gensite passes rulesMeta to formatter rendering (#11567) (Kevin Partington)
    • c06d38c Fix: Allow HTML formatter to handle no meta data (#11566) (Ilya Volodin)
    • 87a5c03 Docs: func-style: clarify when allowArrowFunctions is used (#11548) (Oliver Joseph Ash)
    • bc3e427 Update: pass rule meta to formatters RFC 10 (#11551) (Chris Meyer)
    • b452f27 Chore: Update README to pull in reviewer data (#11506) (Nicholas C. Zakas)

    • f16af43 Chore: fix formatters/table test (#11534) (Toru Nagashima)
    • 78358a8 Docs: fix duplicate punctuation in CLI docs (#11528) (Teddy Katz)
  • 5.15.3 - 2019-03-18
